SEARCH
Package game.actors.npcs.enemies

Class Enemy

java.lang.Object
edu.monash.fit2099.engine.GameEntity
edu.monash.fit2099.engine.actors.Actor
game.actors.npcs.enemies.Enemy
All Implemented Interfaces:
Printable, Resettable
Direct Known Subclasses:
AbxervyerForestWatcher, EldentreeGuardian, ForestKeeper, HollowSoldier, LivingBranch, RedWolf, WanderingUndead
public abstract class Enemy extends Actor implements Resettable
An abstract class representing an enemy actor in the game. Enemy actors are hostile by default and can be attacked by actors with the HOSTILE_TO_ENEMY capability, but are friendly to other enemies.
Author:
Lim Hung Xuan Modified by: Group6

      Determines the action to be performed by the enemy during its turn.
      Specified by:
      playTurn in class Actor
      Parameters:
      actions - A collection of possible actions for the enemy.
      lastAction - The action the enemy took last turn.
      map - The GameMap containing the enemy.
      display - The I/O object to which messages may be written.
      Returns:
      The valid action to be performed during this turn.

      public void addBehaviour(Integer priority, Behaviour behaviour)
      Adds a behavior with a specified priority to the enemy's behavior list.
      Parameters:

      behaviour - The behavior to be added.

    • allowableActions

      public ActionList allowableActions(Actor otherActor, String direction, GameMap map)
      Overrides the allowableActions method to return attack actions if the enemy is hostile to the actor.
      Overrides:
      allowableActions in class Actor
      Parameters:
      otherActor - The actor to check for hostility.
      direction - The direction of the actor relative to this enemy.
      map - The GameMap containing this enemy.
      Returns:
      A list of allowable actions for this enemy based on its hostility towards other actors.

    • getBehaviours

      public Map<Integer,Behaviour> getBehaviours()
      Returns the behaviors associated with this enemy.
      Returns:
      A map of behaviors, where the key is the behavior's priority and the value is the behavior itself.
